nodes.text: K-nearest neighbors (KNN) can be used to accurately predict heart disease from clinical and demographic patient data

Dataset comprises patient records with features age, sex, chest pain type, resting blood pressure, cholesterol, fasting blood sugar, restecg, max heart rate, exercise-induced angina, oldpeak, slope, ca, thal and target label
KNN is a nonparametric, instance based supervised algorithm using distance metrics (Euclidean) to find K nearest neighbors and predict class by majority vote

Research workflow includes feature selection, handling class imbalance via weighting strategies, parameter tuning of K and distance metric, and cross validation with metrics sensitivity, specificity, accuracy and AUC-ROC
Data visualization used histogram plots for each numerical column to inspect distributions
Dataset label encoding: sex (0 female, 1 male), target (1 no heart ailment, 0 yes), thal categories and other feature encodings described
Model configuration reported: repeats = 3, K = 10, distance metric Euclidean, average of three trials used
K selection guidance: odd K preferred to avoid ties; small K risks overfitting, large K introduces noise
Model evaluation employed confusion matrix and computed accuracy from true positives, true negatives, false positives and false negatives
Visualization finding: more male patients diagnosed with heart disease than female patients, attributed to higher cholesterol and resting blood pressure in males
Confusion matrix produced counts yielding accuracy = (38 + 45) / (38 + 10 + 7 + 45) = 83%
Scores of K-neighbors classifier were compared across different K values using Euclidean distance to identify optimal performance
KNN model achieved 83% classification accuracy on the presented dataset
Authors report high AUC-ROC and model sensitivity and specificity from cross validation, indicating promising discrimination ability
Conclusion: KNN is a promising, interpretable tool for heart disease prediction that can assist in risk assessment and early detection when combined with proper preprocessing and feature analysis

Limitations noted: KNN is computationally expensive at classification time, sensitive to K choice, and requires careful preprocessing (scaling, handling missing data); medical diagnosis should involve clinicians
